block.p: Nuclear Test-Ban Pact Rejected in Senate Vote The Senate rejected a treaty banning all underground nuclear testing in a 51-48 vote that was largely along party lines and crushed one of President Clinton's major foreign policy goals.
The President said the fight over the treaty was ''far from over.''

Nuclear Test-Ban Pact Rejected in Senate Vote The Senate rejected a treaty banning all underground nuclear testing in a 51-48 vote that was largely along party lines and crushed one of President Clinton's major foreign policy goals.
The President said the fight over the treaty was ''far from over.''

Aftermath of Pakistan Coup The army chief, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, said in a nationally televised speech that he would soon lay out the army's plans, which could entail martial law, new elections or the installation of a civilian government controlled by the military.
Congress moved to give President Clinton greater flexibility in deciding whether to impose sanctions.

Russian Prosecutor Endures The upper house of Parliament rebuffed President Boris N. Yeltsin's third attempt to get rid of Yuri Skuratov, left, the prosecutor general whose corruption inquiries have crept inside the Kremlin itself.
The Swiss police say investigations into possible money laundering by Russian executives and politicians have expanded to include Lev Cherny, a businessman with interests in the metals industry.

Colombia Pledges Extraditions The Justice Department said officials in Colombia had arrested the head of that country's largest cocaine-trafficking ring and other traffickers and had pledged to extradite them to the United States.

Palestinian Accuses Jailers Maher Dasuki, a talk show host in the West Bank who was jailed after a guest on his show criticized Yasir Arafat, returned to the air and accused his jailers of torturing him.
Fashioning a Ticket President B. J. Habibie of Indonesia invited the military chief, Gen. Wiranto, to be his vice presidential running mate. It was not known if the general had accepted.
Legal Status for Unwed Couples The French Parliament passed legislation giving legal status to unmarried couples, including homosexual unions.
Clinton Vows to Preserve Federal Wilderness Lands President Clinton said he would act to protect at least 40 million acres of forest land from road building, logging and mining permanently.
G.O.P Medicare Proposals Senior Republicans in Congress proposed restoring some of the 1997 Medicare cutbacks, but said they had no plans to add prescription benefits to the program this year.
Senate Approves Farm Aid The Senate gave final legislative approval to $8.7 billion in emergency aid to hard-pressed farmers.

Counsel Clears Babbitt An independent counsel said there was insufficient evidence to bring charges against Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt or anyone else involved in his agency's handling of an Indian gambling project.
Buchanan Near a Decision Patrick J. Buchanan is notifying supporters that he will make a major speech Oct. 25; he is expected to announce his candidacy for the Reform Party's Presidential nomination.
Labor Endorsement for Gore The A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsed Vice President Al Gore for the Presidency, but without the support of two of the nation's most powerful unions, the Teamsters and the U.A.W.

No Charges in Ramsey Case Prosecutors in Boulder, Colo., said they did not have enough evidence to charge anyone with the killing of JonBenet Ramsey in 1996 and dismissed the grand jury that spent 13 months on the case.

State Sues Over Lead Paint The Rhode Island Attorney General sued eight paint manufacturers and an industry trade group seeking to make them pay for treating children poisoned by lead paint and for the removal of paint from buildings.

Racial Disparity in Lung Cancer Black patients with early stage lung cancer are less likely than whites to undergo life-saving surgery, a study found, and as a result are more likely to die of their disease.
Cancer-Resistant Mice Scientists have developed a strain of mouse that is immune to certain types of cancer.

Pataki to Order Changes To Cut Air Pollution Governor Pataki will order power plants in the state to make sharp cuts in smokestack emissions that cause acid rain and smog, aides said. The move will raise electricity rates by 1 to 2 percent, they said, but will put New York ahead of the rest of the country in the cleanup schedule set by the Federal Clean Air Act.

2 Killed in SoHo Holdup An owner and a manager of a SoHo muffin shop were shot to death and two other people were wounded during a botched robbery that ended with a gunfight between the robbers and undercover officers, officials said. Two suspects were arrested.

No De Niro Navy Yard Deal A tentative deal for the actor Robert De Niro and Miramax Films to develop a $150 million soundstage complex at the Brooklyn Navy Yard has collapsed, Mayor Giuliani said, though a studio will still be built, but by other developers.
Yankees Win, Mets Lose The Yankees beat the Red Sox, 4-3, in the first game of the A.L. Championship series. The Braves beat the Mets, 4-3, to take a 2-0 lead in their series.

Holocaust Memoir Withdrawn The German publisher Suhrkamp Verlag said it was withdrawing all hardcover copies of ''Fragments,'' by Binjamin Wilkomirksi, after serious questions were raised about the author.
National Book Awards The finalists list is as notable for the titles that are not on it -- ''Dutch'' and '' 'Tis'' -- as for those that are -- ''Waiting'' and ''Vice: New and Selected Poems.''

Nobel Award for Economist Robert A. Mundell, 67, of Columbia University, who helped to frame the supply-side economic theories that strongly influenced the Reagan Administration, received the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science.
Tyco Shares Plummet Criticism from just one investment manager sent prices for one of the decade's best-performing stocks, Tyco International, plunging, which led to a halt in its trading.

Stocks Continue to Slide Stocks fell sharply for a second consecutive session as Intel's disappointing earnings report on Tuesday undermined technology shares and a plunge in bond prices dragged the broader market lower. The Dow fell 184.90 points, to 10,232.16, the S.& P. 500 declined 27.49 points, to 1,285.55, and the Nasdaq dropped 71.16 points, to 2,801.27. The price of the 30-year bond fell 20/32, to 98 1/32, and its yield rose to 6.27 percent.
Editorials: A damaging arms control defeat; the truth about tobacco; new risk for campaign law.
